G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 and 21.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 and 21, as the amount in controversy is less than $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 because the property at issue is located within this Court’s jurisdictional district.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord may not “directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of his premises.”

Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease in Massachusetts.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses an implied obligation arising from the grant in a lease—that the lessor will refrain from voluntarily undertaken acts that substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises—but it does not state that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease, or in all leases generally. The case is about a commercial dental office lease and treats quiet enjoyment primarily in the context of potential tort and nuisance liability, not as a universal implied covenant in residential tenancies. Thus it does not affirm the broad proposition claimed.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.relevant_excerpt: “The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Brande v. Grace, supra, page 212.… The same act may be a breach of the covenant for quiet enjoyment and also a wrong causing injury to the tenant for which injunctive relief might be sought or an action of tort would lie.”

Davis v. Comerford, 483 Mass. 164, 167 (.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease in Massachusetts.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.proposition: Defendant’s failure to take reasonable measures to address repeated, severe disturbances caused by other tenants under his control constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.support_reasoning: The court held that the landlords breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment—amounting to constructive eviction—because severe, repeated noise and disturbances from another tenant’s lounge, over which the landlords had the right and ability to exercise control, substantially deprived the residential tenants of quiet enjoyment. The opinion emphasizes that the landlords’ failure to effectively correct the condition, despite notice and some efforts, resulted in a substantial interference with habitability and justified nonpayment of rent. This directly supports the proposition that failing to take reasonable measures to address serious disturbances by tenants under the landlord’s control constitutes substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.relevant_excerpt: “The judge further found that, although the landlords did not intend to create the conditions, the landlords ‘had it within their control to correct the conditions which... amounted to a constructive eviction of each [tenant].’… We conclude that, as matter of law, the landlords had a right to control the objectionable noise coming from the lounge… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Defendant’s failure to take reasonable measures to address repeated, severe disturbances caused by other tenants under his control constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The case does address interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but the interference here arises from unsanitary physical conditions (repeated flooding) that the landlord failed to repair, not from disturbances caused by other tenants under the landlord’s control. The court expressly rejects the landlord’s attempt to blame third parties by emphasizing that the flooding was a preventable condition the landlord had a duty to correct, but it does not involve or discuss disturbances such as noise or misconduct by other tenants. Thus, it supports landlord liability for failure to address repeated, severe *physical* conditions, not for disturbances caused by other tenants.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “As its third objection to Solomon’s recovery on her count for interference with quiet enjoyment, Gem asserts that it was wrongly held responsible for the actions of third parties beyond its control. Pointing to its plumber’s testimony that waste backups were caused by tenants’ using unauthorized washing machines or introducing objects into the waste stacks, and to its unsuccessful attempts to evict tenants for using washing machines in their apartments, Gem argues that it was unable to control the source of the flooding… The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.proposition: Defendant’s inaction amounts to an “indirect interference” prohibited by statute.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.support_reasoning: The opinion construes G.L. c. 186, § 14’s "directly or indirectly" interference language to require at least negligent conduct plus notice or reason to know of the condition; it does not treat mere inaction, without fault, as a per se prohibited "indirect interference." The court holds that violation of the lead paint statute alone (i.e., strict liability without proof of negligent inaction after notice) is not enough to establish a § 14 violation. Thus, it does not support the proposition that defendant’s inaction, by itself, automatically amounts to an "indirect interference" prohibited by statute.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.relevant_excerpt: Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.

Berman v. Linnane, 434 Mass. 301, 303 n..proposition: Defendant’s inaction amounts to an “indirect interference” prohibited by statute.
Berman v. Linnane, 434 Mass. 301, 303 n..support_reasoning: The opinion deals with attorney’s fees and the joinder of the real party in interest under Rules 15 and 17(a); it does not interpret or apply any statute concerning “indirect interference,” nor does it address whether a defendant’s inaction can constitute such interference. Nothing in the reasoning or holding touches on interference-by-inaction or a statutory prohibition of indirect interference. The citation is therefore not supporting the stated proposition and appears contextually unrelated to that legal concept.
Berman v. Linnane, 434 Mass. 301, 303 n..relevant_excerpt: “By statute, a judge has discretion to permit amendment of a complaint at any time to add a real party in interest, and the amendment may relate back to the original pleading. See G. L. c. 231, § 51. Such authority is also conferred by rules 15 and 17 (a). … One purpose of rule 17 (a) is to prevent forfeiture of an action.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Plaintiff’s deprivation of peaceful habitation constitutes the “substantial interference” required for statutory liability.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that the landlord’s failure to provide heat constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and creates liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14, regardless of financial inability. However, the opinion does not frame the violation in terms of "deprivation of peaceful habitation" or analyze a separate "substantial interference" requirement; it instead relies on statutory and covenant concepts and prior case law. Thus it supports liability for lack of heat as interference with quiet enjoyment, but not specifically the articulated "substantial interference" formulation.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season ... seriously “impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises” ... and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. ... [L]iability will be imposed “whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.” ... On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14; (b) an injunction ...; and (c) an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Plaintiff’s deprivation of peaceful habitation constitutes the “substantial interference” required for statutory liability.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly states that if the tenants are unable to use the common areas due to pervasive crime, that situation "constitutes a serious interference" with quiet enjoyment and "substantially impairs the character of the leased premises." It then remands for fact-finding on "the seriousness or substantiality of the interference," confirming that such deprivation of peaceful habitation can satisfy the substantial/serious interference element for statutory quiet enjoyment liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: "In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. ... There must be a trial to determine what, if any, measures the defendant has taken ... and to determine the seriousness or substantiality of the interference with the tenancies."

Cruickshank v. Dukakis, 840 F.2d 1020, 1.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was willful and in disregard of Plaintiff’s statutory rights, warranting an award of treble damages, costs, and reasonable attorney’s fees.
Cruickshank v. Dukakis, 840 F.2d 1020, 1.case_name: Leslie Fudge v. Penthouse International, Ltd., Leslie Fudge v. Penthouse International, Ltd.
Cruickshank v. Dukakis, 840 F.2d 1020, 1.support_reasoning: The opinion is a First Circuit defamation/false light/emotional distress case that addresses Rule 11 sanctions and the standard for ‘extreme and outrageous’ conduct, but it does not involve any statute authorizing treble damages, nor does it make findings about a defendant’s willful disregard of statutory rights. It actually affirms denial of sanctions and rejects liability, rather than finding willful misconduct warranting enhanced remedies. Thus it does not support the proposition that a defendant’s willful conduct in disregard of statutory rights warrants treble damages, costs, and attorney’s fees.
Cruickshank v. Dukakis, 840 F.2d 1020, 1.relevant_excerpt: “There remains the issue of Rule 11 sanctions, requested by Penthouse against plaintiffs and their attorney and refused by the district court. Penthouse, arguing that the action was frivolous, sought to recover its attorney's fees and the costs of removing and defending the action. The district court concluded that ‘[t]hough plaintiffs’ claims have been denied, they do not rise to the level of frivolity necessary for imposition of Rule 11 sanctions.’ … We therefore do not think it an abuse of discretion to conclude that this action was ‘warranted by existing law or a good faith argument….’”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 908 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was willful and in disregard of Plaintiff’s statutory rights, warranting an award of treble damages, costs, and reasonable attorney’s fees.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion does not find that Young’s conduct was willful or in disregard of statutory rights so as to warrant treble damages under the Boston rent control ordinance; in fact, it affirms the trial judge’s finding that the rent overcharge was not willful. The court does award treble damages, costs, and attorney’s fees, but only for the security deposit violations under G. L. c. 186, § 15B(7), based on failure to comply and failure to return the deposit on demand, not based on a finding of willfulness. Thus, using this case to show a willful-disregard finding is inaccurate.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “The judge’s finding that Young’s violation was not wilful is not clearly erroneous, as Young could easily have had the property decontrolled much earlier. The tenant is, however, entitled to attorney’s fees and costs under the ordinance… A showing that a violation is neither wilful nor the result of failure to take practicable precautions merely limits the amount of liquidated damages to the amount of the overcharge… We thus agree with the tenant that subsection (7) is applicable to these circumstances and, accordingly, that Young is liable for treble damages, interest, costs, and attorney’s fees.”
